description: Borrowed from French boulevardier, from boulevard  +â€Ž -ier.

entries.meaning: A man who frequents the boulevards; thus, a man about town or bon vivant.
examples: Sitting alone at his window-seat, he was like an old boulevardier fallen on hard times, waspish, inward, slothful.

entries.meaning: (often capitalized) An alcoholic drink similar to a negroni but made with bourbon instead of gin.

verbs.description: boulevardier (third-person singular simple present boulevardiers, present participle boulevardiering, simple past and past participle boulevardiered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To strut or show off like a boulevardier.
examples: One spectacular being clothed liked a boulevardiering cavalier and having the mein of a finished chesterfieldian gentleman was noted seated in an oak near the cabin one day. ... It was a northern butcher-bird, the aggressive shrike ....
